arm_group.description: Healthy subjects with no migraine as control

brief_summary.textblock:
The researchers investigated the relationship between migraine and allergy. For this
      purpose, the researchers designed a controlled study to evaluate nasal symptoms and signs;
      and to perform Specific Immunoglobulin E  (IgE) measurements in migraine patients and
      healthy subjects. According to these results the prevalence of allergic rhinitis in migraine
      group was planned to be compared to that of the healthy controls, statistically.

clinical_study.brief_title: Is There a Comorbidity Between Migraine and Allergic Rhinitis?

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  patients with migraine

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  other neurologic disorders that may contribute to headaches, such as stroke, cerebral
             palsy, trigeminal neuralgia, and seizure disorder

          -  also acute and chronic sinusitis.

study_pop.textblock: Migraine patients attending neurology clinic and healthy subjects

other_outcome.description: inferior concha colour (0=natural, 1=pale, 2=bluish and 3=severely pale or bluish) and turbinate edema were assessed during ENT examination on 0-3 scale (0 = no, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe).

primary_outcome.description: Blood samples were taken from study and control group for the determination of Specific IgE panel against six different allergens: (1) fungi, (2) grass pollens, (3) tree pollens, (4) wild herbs, (5) mite 1, (6) mite 2. For all of specific IgE panels, <0,7 RU/ml was negative; and >0,7 RU/ml was Positive.

Symptoms were assessed with a questionnaire for the presence and severity of allergic rhinitis (AR) symptoms on a scale of 0-3 (0 = none, 1 = mild, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe). Symptoms of AR (Nasal discharge, nasal congestion, itching and sneezing) were graded between 0-3.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
